dialogues.text: Usually more students are sent down to me.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I try to take care of things myself.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That can be an error. You are answerable to me, I to the Monsignor, he to the Bishop, and so on up to the Holy Father. There is a chain. Make use of it. (Discovers a small box. Inquires.) Candy?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Cough drops.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Candy by another name. Sister Aloysius throws the box in the wastebasket. She ge up.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: How is Donald Miller doing?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Steady.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Good. (Points to a back corner chair) That girl...Noreen Horan.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’ve seated her as far away from the boys as possible. Doesn’t do much good. Sister Aloysius has gone to Noreen’s desk and finds the barrette; she examines it in the sunlight as if it’s a mu weapon. She works it. It looks like little legs spreading (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Just get her through. Intact.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO AN OPEN WINDOW AS A GUST OF WIND PROPELS DEAD LEAV
dialogues.text: Into the classroom and on to the floor. Sister Aloysius g to the window and shuts it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What’s this? The wind is so...peripatetic this year. Is that the word I want? SISTER ALOYSIUS’ TIED-IN POV DOWN TO THE STREET We faintly hear Father Flynn share convivial chat with th OLD MONSIGNOR on the street.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIGNOR
dialogues.text: Wasn’t that a fine cut of beef for dinner, Father Flynn?!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: It was, Monsignor, very good. Though I believe it was chicken.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIGNOR
dialogues.text: Was it a chicken? Yes, I guess it was a chicken. It was very good. The old man pats the younger man’s shoulder warmly. After a moment, we hear a timid Sister James.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No. Why? Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, then, nothing’s the matter then. Another silence. Sister James doesn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes. The older nun picks something off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: A pen?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: A ballpoint pen. The students are not using them for assignments, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I allowed even cartridge pens into this school. Always the easy way out these days. Every easy choice today will have its consequence tomorrow. Mark my words. Sister James picks up dead leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Ballpoints make them press down, when they press down, they write like monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t allow them ballpoint pens.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: And yet here one is. Penmanship is dying all across this country. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I hope not. Sister Aloysius starts to walk out and stops, examining t top of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You should frame something. Put it up on the blackboard. (Picking up a framed photograph.) Put the Pope up.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s the wrong Pope. He’s deceased.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I don’t care what Pope it is. Use the glass to see behind you. The children should think you have eyes in the back of your head.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Wouldn't that be a little frightening?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Only to the ones who are up to no good. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Relax. Put it up there. William shoots and misses.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: All right, now. Jimmy swaps positions and moves onto the foul line.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: The thing about shooting from the foul line (Points at Jimmy’s head.) is it’s psychological. All right, come up with a routine. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, shift your weight, move your hips... The boys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Hey, you think that’s funny, Ralph? You know what’s funny is you never getting a foul shot.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Oooh.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: All right, concentrate on the routine, and you'll forget to get tensed up. All right, go ahead, Jimmy. Jimmy shoots and gets it in. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Good man. You listen. That’s good. All right, now sit down. Everyone. Good. On another matter, I’ve noticed several of you guys got dirty nails. All right, I don’t want to see that. I’m not talking about the length of your nails, I’m talking about cleanliness. See? Look at my nails.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All right, they’re long, I like them a little long, but look at how clean they are. That makes it okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monsignor, FATHER SHERMAN, and Flynn are eating a roa and washing it down with red wine. Boisterous laughter. T Monsignor is smoking a cigarette. The pack is on the tabl Pall Mall unfiltered. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: The climpity-clomp. Clomp clomp clomp. Harder than a herd of elephants.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIGNOR
dialogues.text: You are wicked!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No, I told her, “You’re her mother! You raised her, you fed her, YOU tell her she’s fat!”

dialogues.speaker: MONSIGNOR
dialogues.text: Ooh!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER SHERMAN
dialogues.text: But wait, how fat is she?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What, the mother or the daughter?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER SHERMAN
dialogues.text: The daughter.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I never met the daughter.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER SHERMAN
dialogues.text: What about the mother?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Fat!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner’s in progress. The Nuns eat. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Flynn is serving with Jimmy and Donald Miller as a boys. Flynn lifts the host and recites the blessing of th Eucharist. Jimmy rings the bells. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Domini nostri Jesu Christi. Qui pridie quam pateretur, accepit panem in sanctas ac venerabiles manus suas et elevatis oculis in coelum, ad te Deum Patrem suum omnipotentem, tibi gratias agens, benedixit, fregit, deditque discipulis suis, dicens: ‘Accipite, et manducate ex hoc omnes. Hoc est enim Corpus meum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donald is in his school clothes. Dimly, in the distant sacristy, Flynn can be seen talking with Jimmy. Donald di hears Flynn and Jimmy talking.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Father, we having practice after school?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: If you guys want it, we can have it. Let me know. INT. SISTER JAMES’ CLASSROOM — DAY William London sneaks across the back of the classroom an whispers to Noreen Horan, and she giggles.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES SEES THIS REFLECTED IN THE GLASS OF THE PHOT
dialogues.text: She speaks without turning.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: The Fascist governments of Germany and Italy were already working together. They formed the Pact of Steel. The Pact of Steel was a military alliance between Benito Mussolini and Adolf Hitler. Mister London, get back in your seat and stop bothering Miss Horan, please. WILLIAM'S REACTION - HE’S SPOOKED THAT THE SISTER KNEW

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SISTER JAMES WHO SMILES AT HER LITTLE VICTORY
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Now, who can tell me - - The intercom buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES ANSWERING THE INTERCOM
dialogues.text: We hear Flynn’s voice, but not what he’s saying. Sister J replies.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes? Yes. Of course, Father. She gets off the intercom and turns to the class.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Donald? You should go to the Rectory.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: MRS. SHIELDS is a middle-aged woman in a dress and silver shoes. BLAME IT ON THE BOSSANOVA is on the record player.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SHIELDS
dialogues.text: Two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven. They dance facing their partners. A few of the girls sing along.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SHIELDS
dialogues.text: Go one, two, three, touch. One, two, three, kick. Back, side, front, kick. Back, side, front... Raymond is doing the mashed potato. Mrs. Shields moves to him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SHIELDS
dialogues.text: Raymond, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: The mashed potato.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SHIELDS
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be doing the bossa nova. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: But I know the mashed potato.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SHIELDS
dialogues.text: (laughs) All right, now follow. Back, side, front, kick. Back, side, one, two, three, kick. Back, side, front, kick. Back, side, front. Okay. Let me get in front of you so that you can see what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES IS SITTING ON A FOLDING CHAIR WATCHING
dialogues.text: Amused. She claps lightly. Then she sees something. SISTER JAMES’ POV - SOME LOCKERS - FLYNN APPEARS He is somewhat furtive. He has something white in his han He opens a locker and puts the white thing in. It’s fabri He sees Sister James and smiles. He takes a sip of water from the drinking fountain and goes back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES SLOWLY WALKING TOWARDS THE LOCKERS
dialogues.text: She goes to the locker. She opens it, a boy’s white T-shi She returns it to the locker puzzled. INT. THE HALLWAY - SISTER JAMES’ STUDENTS LEAVING - DAY INT. SISTER JAMES’ CLASSROOM - DAY Jimmy’s got his school bag. Others are heading out. He lo at Sister James, who is intently talking to one of the students. JIMMY’S POV - SISTER JAMES’ BACK Her habit obscures the identity of the student she’s talk to. Sister James leans down towards the unseen boy’s face

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Donald, are you feeling ill?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (UNSEEN)
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: You sure? Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JIMMY LOOKING AS HE GOES
dialogues.text: A shadow passes over his expression. BACK TO JIMMY’S POV of SISTER JAMES’ BACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister James comes out of the convent. Sister Aloysius is unrolling burlap. Sister James sees her and walks over.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Sister James.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Sister, can I speak with you about Donald Miller? Sister Aloysius rolls the barrow onto a path. Sister Jame follows. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AN OLD UTILITY SHED AS SISTER ALOYSIUS OPENS IT
dialogues.text: Accompanied by Sister James.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Is he being accepted?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: He has no friends.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That would be a lot to expect after only two months. Has anyone hit him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Someone will. And when that happens, send them right down to me. Sister Aloysius stows the contents of the barrow in the s as Sister James continues.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure anyone will.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: This parish serves Irish and Italian families. Someone will hit Donald Miller.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: He has a protector.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Father Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to face Sister James.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What? Sister James becomes elaborately casual.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s taken an interest.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I told you to come to me, but I hoped you never would. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Maybe I shouldn’t have.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: So it’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: What!? Oh, no. I’m not telling you that! I’m not even certain what you mean. MR. MCGUINN throws open the rear door, startling them. He putting away the garden hose.

dialogues.speaker: MCGUINN
dialogues.text: Oh excuse me there, Sisters!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No bother we’re done here! Come, Sister. They start to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Aloysius is hustling Sister James through the door Stops in shadow and asks.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What have you seen?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: It is unsettling to look at people with suspicion. I feel less close to God.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: When you take a step to address wrongdoing, you are taking a step away from God, but in His service. What have you seen? The housekeeper, Mrs. Carson appears with a cat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARSON
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Sisters! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mrs. Carson. Why the cat?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARSON
dialogues.text: Because there’s a mouse. Want some tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flynn has the BOYS arrayed around the table.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: If you don’t want to dance with her, don’t dance with her.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well, is it wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: But what if the girl turns you down?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: All right, you have the right to ask a girl to dance. All right, she has the right to turn you down. The trick is don’t take it to heart.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: What if they ALL turn you down?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Well, then you become a priest. They all laugh. Jimmy is thoughtful. Raymond raises his hand and Flynn calls on him.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: All right, next question. INT. THE CONVENT’S BLUE SITTING ROOM - THE TWO NUNS - DAY (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister James is seated. Sister Aloysius is closing the do

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What have you seen?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: He called Donald Miller to the Rectory.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: A talk.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: A week ago, during class.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I didn’t think there was anything wrong with it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Of all the children. Donald Miller. I suppose it makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: How does it make sense?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: He’s isolated.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t know that anything is wrong! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Our first Negro student. I thought there would be fighting. A parent or two to deal with. I should have foreseen this possibility.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: How could you imagine it?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, it’s my job to outshine the fox in cleverness. That is my job!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: But maybe it’s nothing! Sister Aloysius sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Then why do you look like you've seen the Devil?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: It’s just the way the boy acted when he came back to class.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: He said something?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: No. It was his expression. He looked frightened and... he put his head on the desk in the most peculiar way. And... (Struggles) And one other thing. I think there was alcohol on his breath. There WAS alcohol on his breath. Sister Aloysius puts a consoling hand on Sister James’ ha

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Years ago at St. Boniface there was a priest... But I had Father Scully then. Here there’s no man I can go to, men run everything. We are going to have to stop him ourselves. Mrs. Carson barges in with the dead mouse in a napkin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARSON
dialogues.text: There we go! She got him! It takes a cat.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes it does. Yes it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children exiting the school as a storm gathers.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SISTER JAMES’ BEDROOM - NIGHT There’s a storm raging outside. Wind and rain. She tries sleep, but a tree branch claws the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is lifting a kettle off the gas range as a commotion in the hall catches her attention.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARSON
dialogues.text: This towel will never be dead white again.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes it will. Sister Raymond is helping Sister Veronica to her room.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER RAYMOND, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Carson!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER VERONICA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER RAYMOND
dialogues.text: There’s a branch down.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (To Veronica.) Are you alright, Sister? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER RAYMOND
dialogues.text: She didn’t see it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER VERONICA
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Just bushwhacked. No need for a fuss.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You just go lie down. I'll bring you some tea. Sister Aloysius is beleaguered, but not alarmed. She unho the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (On intercom. ) Come on. Mister McGuinn? Could you look in on the courtyard? A branch has fallen. A branch has - -! (slams down receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuinn is tugging at the fallen branch, which is lar Sister Aloysius comes out with a pot of tea in a towel an steps around the situation.

dialogues.speaker: MCGUINN
dialogues.text: Watch your step here, Sister. I'll cut it up.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: The world is crashing, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MCGUINN
dialogues.text: I haven't heard a wind like that since I left Mullingar!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’ve never known a wind like it. The wind has changed. She goes on as he tugs. cuT TO  38. INT. THE ENTRANCE DOOR TO THE PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY A bench outside this door. The boy, Conroy, sits. Flynn joins him.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here, Conroy?

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I talked in class, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Waiting for Sister Aloysius. She know you’re here?

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: She knows. Father The door opens suddenly. It’s Sister Aloysius. The men st

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Father Flynn. Good of you to come by.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sister Aloysius. How are you today?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m very well, thank you. (Shifts attention.) Mister Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Mister Transistor Radio. Multiplication table ten times in its totality delivered to me tomorrow morning. Legible, Boy! Return to class. Go. Go, go. Conroy, miserable, goes. Sister Aloysius addresses Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I'd invite you in, but we’re just short Sister James. Hear that wind last night? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I certainly did! Conversation dries up.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Did I hear Sister Veronica had an accident?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister Veronica fell and practically killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Is she alright?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, she’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Her sight isn’t good, is it?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (Lying) Her sight is fine. Nuns fall, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Nah, I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: It’s the habit. It catches us up more often than not. We go down like dominoes. Sister James appears, running down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Am I past the time?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Good morning, Father. Good morning, Sister. I’m sorry I was delayed. I ran into Sister Veronica.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: How is she? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m afraid she has a bit of a bloody nose.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m beginning to think you're punching people.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Sister?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: First William London and now ... Never mind. Well, come in, please.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Sister... INT. THE PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY Sister Aloysius is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Please. Sit. Have a seat. They come in.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I actually have a hot pot of tea. (Closes the door but for an inch.) And close this but not quite for form's sake. Father, would you care for a... Sister Aloysius is offering Flynn a chair, but he doesn’t notice. He sits in Sister Aloysius’ chair, at her desk. She’s taken aback, but recovers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Would you have a cup of tea, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I would love a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Sister, perhaps you could serve him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’d be glad.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: And yourself, of course.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Would you like a cup of tea, Sister Aloysius?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No, I’ve already had my cup.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Is there sugar?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Sugar? Yes! (Goes to her desk, rummages in a drawer.) Yes. It’s somewhere here. I put it in the drawer for Lent last year and never remembered to take it out.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: (Winking at Sister James) Ah, it mustn’t have been much to give up then.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m sure you’re right. Here it is. I’ll serve you, though for want of practice, I’m, I’m a little clumsy. She's come to him with the sugar bowl. She’s poised over with a lump of sugar in a small pair of tongs.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I see your fingernails. SISTER ALOYSIUS’ POV - FLYNN’S LONG NAILS

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I wear them a little long. The sugar? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes. One?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Three? She's appalled and tries to hide it.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Sweet tooth. She digs at the sugar because the cubes have melded toget

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: One. Two. Three. Sister, you care for sugar?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Never! (Gently, to Flynn.) Not that there’s anything wrong with sugar. Sister Aloysius puts the sugar away in her desk.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, Father, for making time for us. We are at our wit’s end.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Well, I think it’s an excellent idea to rethink the Christmas pageant. ‘Cause last year’s effort was a little woebegone.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh, I loved it! But I love all pageants. The hymns! O Little Town of Bethlehem, O Come O Come Emmanuel, O Come All Ye Faithful - -

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: All right. Thank you, Sister James! So what do you think, Father? Is there something new we could do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Well, we all love the Christmas hymns, but it might be jolly to include a secular song.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Secular?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Yes. IT’S BEGINNING TO LOOK A LOT LIKE CHRISTMAS. Something like that. Sister Aloysius gets up.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What would be the point of a secular song?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Just fun.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Or FROSTY THE SNOWMAN.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s a good one. We could have one of the boys dress as a snowman and dance around. Sister Aloysius flips the blinds. A shaft of sunlight bla on the priest.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Which boy?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: (Squinting) We'd do tryouts.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: FROSTY THE SNOWMAN espouses a pagan belief in magic. The snowman comes to life when an enchanted hat is put on his head. If the music were more somber, people would realize the images are disturbing and the song heretical. Sister James and Father Flynn exchange a look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’ve never thought about Frosty The Snowman like that.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, it should be banned from the airwaves.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: So. Not FROSTY THE SNOWMAN. He writes something in a small notebook.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, IT’S BEGINNING TO LOOK LIKE - - A LOT LIKE CHRISTMAS would be fine, I suppose. Parents would like it. May I ask what you’re writing down? With that ballpoint pen?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Oh. Nothing. It’s an idea for a sermon.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You had one right now?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I get them all the time.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: How fortunate.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I forget them so I have to write them down.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh. What is the idea?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Intolerance. Sister James tries to break the tension.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Would you like a little more tea, Father? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Not yet. (To Sister Aloysius) It’s a new time, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What’s new about it?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Something inside of people is new.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: There is nothing new under the sun.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: The Church needs to change. We should sing a song from the radio now and then. Take the kids out for ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Sweet tooth.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Maybe take the boys on a camping trip.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: The point being?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: We should be friendlier. You know, the children and the parents should see us as members of their family.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: But we are not members of their family. We’re different.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why? Because of our vows?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Precisely.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I don’t think we're so different. You know, Sister, I would take some more tea. Flynn gets up. Sister James gets up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: And they think we’re different, yeah? The working class people of this parish trust us to be different. Flynn flips the blinds closed.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I think we’re getting off the subject.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes, you’re right. You're right. Back to it. The wall intercom rings. She answers it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister Raymond? (Listens.) Well you tell her to wash her face and her neck and report to me at three. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (turning on the desk lamp) Excuse me. The Christmas pageant. We must be careful how Donald Miller is used in the pageant. Sister James shakes as she pours the tea, spilling a litt

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Easy there, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, yes, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: All right, what about Donald Miller?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: We must be careful, in the pageant, that we neither hide Donald Miller nor put him forward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Because of the color of his skin?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That's right, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh come, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I think he should be treated like every other boy.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, you yourself singled the boy out for special attention. You held a private meeting with him at the Rectory. (Shooting a look at Sister James) A week ago?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes. Flynn picks a lemon drop out of the bag.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Donald Miller?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: The boy acted strangely when he returned to class. The priest turns to Sister James, popping a lemon drop in mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: When he returned from the Rectory. A little odd, yes.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Can you tell us why? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: How did he act strangely?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: He...I’m not sure how to explain it. He...he laid his head on the desk, and he...some...

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Do you mean you had some impression?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: And he’d come from the Rectory so you're asking me?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Mmhmmm.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Mm-hmmm. Hmmm. Did you want to discuss the pageant, is that why I’m here, or is this what you wanted to discuss?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: This.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Well. I’m a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why do you think? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: The boy’s well-being is my responsibility. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: His well-being is not at issue. DUTCH ANGLE OF PHONE ON SISTER ALOYSIUS’ DESK It rings. She doesn’t answer it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m not satisfied that that is true. He was upset when he returned to class.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Did he say something?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What happened in the Rectory?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Happened?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Mmmhmm.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Nothing happened. I had a talk with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Private matter.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: He’s twelve years old. What could be private?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Should I get the phone--?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (overlaps) No.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I object to your tone.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: This is not about my tone... or your tone, Father Flynn. It’s about arriving at the truth. The phone stops ringing.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You know what I’m talking about. Don’t you? You’re controlling the expression on your face right now. Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: My face? What exactly are you accusing me of?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I am not accusing you of anything, Father Flynn. I am asking you to tell me what happened in the Rectory.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I don’t wish to continue this. And if you're dissatisfied with that, I suggest you speak to Monsignor Benedict. I can only imagine this unfortunate behavior is the result of overwork. Have a good morning. Sister. (To Sister James) Sister. Flynn heads for the door.  51. INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY Sister Aloysius follows him to the door. What she says st him.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: There was alcohol on his breath. Flynn turns.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: When he returned from his meeting with you.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I did smell it on his breath.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Let this alone.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No. A bell rings. Students start coming down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is pensive, troubled. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Take your time, Father. Would you like some more tea?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You should’ve let it alone.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Not possible. Sister Aloysius backs away from him. Sister James sits do (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuinn caught Donald drinking altar wine. When I found out, I sent for him. There were tears. And he begged not to be removed from the altar boys. I took pity on him. I told him if no one else found out, I would let him stay on. Sister James leaps to her feet, overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh, what a relief! That explains everything! Thanks be to God! Look, Sister, it was all a mistake! Sister Aloysius is unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: And if I talk to Mr. McGuinn?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Oh, talk to him by all means. But now that the boy’s secret’s out, I’m going to have to remove him from the altar boys. That’s what I was trying to avoid.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: You were trying to protect the boy!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I might have done the same thing! (To Sister Aloysius) Is there a way Donald could stay on the altar boys?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: If the boy drank altar wine, he can’t continue as an altar boy.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Of course. Are you satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Well, I’1l be going. I have some writing to do.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Intolerance.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That's right. I’m not pleased with how you handled this, Sister. Sister. He goes. Sister James weakly launches into optimism.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Well. What a relief! He cleared it all up.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You believe him?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Isn't it that it’s easier to believe him?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: But we can corroborate his story with Mr. McGuinn.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Mmm...hmm. Yes. These types of people are clever.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, I’m convinced!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You're not. You just want things to be resolved so you can have simplicity back.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I want no further part of this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I'll bring him down.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: How can you be so sure that he is lying?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Experience.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: You just don’t like him! You don’t like it that he uses a ballpoint pen. You don’t like it that he takes three lumps of sugar in his tea. You don’t like it that he likes FROSTY THE SNOWMAN. And you're letting that convince you of something terrible, just terrible! Well, I like FROSTY THE SNOWMAN! And I think it would be nice if this school weren’t run like a jail! And I think it’s a good thing I love to teach History and that I might inspire my students to love it, too! And if you judge that to mean that I’m not fit to be a teacher, then so be it!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Sit down. Sister James immediately complies. The light bulb over he head flashes and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Look at that. You blew out my light. In ancient Sparta, important matters were decided by who shouted loudest. Fortunately, we are not in ancient Sparta. You honestly find the students in this school to be treated like inmates in a prison?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: No. Actually, they all seem fairly happy. But they’re all uniformly terrified of you! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s how it works. Sister Aloysius looks up a phone number on an index card.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Sit there. She dials a number. Speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Sister Aloysius Beauvier, principal at St. Nicholas School. Is this Mrs. Miller? I’m calling about your son, Donald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s raining a bit. Umbrellas.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: A woman was gossiping with a friend about a man she hardly knew-- I know none of you have ever done this--

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: --that night she had a dream. A great hand appeared over her and pointed down at her.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY IS SERVING AS ALTAR BOY
dialogues.text: It’s a story and he likes stories.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: She was immediately seized with an overwhelming sense of guilt. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day she went to confession. She got the old parish priest, Father O’Rourke, and she told him the whole thing. “Is gossiping a sin?” she asked the old man. “Was that the hand of God Almighty pointing a finger at me?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Should I be asking your absolution? Father, tell me, have I done something wrong?” (Irish Brogue) “Yes!” Father O’Rourke answered her.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Yes, you ignorant, badly brought-— up female! You have borne false witness against your neighbor, you have played fast and loose with his reputation, and you should be heartily ashamed!”

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: So the woman said she was sorry and asked for forgiveness. “Not so fast!” says O’Rourke. “I want you to go home, take a pillow up on your roof, cut it open with a knife, and return here to me!” cuT TO JIMMY

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So the woman went home, took a pillow off her bed, a knife from the drawer, went up the fire escape to the roof, and stabbed the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FLYNN
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Then she went back to the old parish priest as instructed. “Did you gut the pillow with the knife?” he says.”Yes, Father.” “And what was the result?” “Feathers,” she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A world of feathers.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Feathers?” he repeated. “Feathers everywhere, Father!”

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOF
dialogues.text: She's watching the feathers flying away on the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Now I want you to go back and gather up every last feather that flew out on the wind!”

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Well,” she said, “it can’t be done. I don’t know where they went. The wind took them all over.”

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: "And that,” said Father O’Rourke, “is gossip!”

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please rise.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Sister James turning back to look at Sister Aloysius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feathers fly away into the morning light. The sound of a breeze.

dialogues.speaker: A CROW CAWS.
dialogues.text: We start on a letter and find Sister James, who sits broo on a bench. She puts the envelope away, hears the crow ca and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SISTER JAMES LOOKING UP AT THE BIRD
dialogues.text: The voice of Father Flynn makes her look around.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s that bird complaining about?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What kind of bird is that? That a starling? A grackle?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: A crow.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: ‘Course it is. Are you praying? I didn’t mean to interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m not praying, no.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You seem subdued. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh. I can’t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Bad dreams.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can’t sleep on occasion.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Why? Do you see that big hand pointing a finger at you?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Yes. Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Was your sermon directed at anyone in particular?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What do you think? Flynn lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I received a letter from my brother in Maryland. He’s very sick.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Then maybe you should go and see him.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I can’t leave my class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flynn smokes his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: You know what I’m asking.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I saw you put an undershirt in Donald Miller's locker.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: He left it in the sacristy.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you hand it to him?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’m trying to spare him further embarrassment. Sister James shakes her head

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: (moves next to her on the bench) It’s me that cares about that child, not her. Has she ever reached out a hand? That black boy needs help or he’s not going to make it! If she has her way, he’ll be left to his own undoing. Why do you think he drank the wine? He’s in trouble! And she sees me talk in a human way to these kids and she immediately assumes that there must be something wrong with it. Well, I’m not going to let her keep this parish in the dark ages! And I’m not going to let her destroy my spirit of compassion!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m sure that’s not her intent.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That I care about this congregation! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I know you do.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Like you care about your class! You love them, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: And that’s natural. How else would you relate to children? That I can look at your face and know your philosophy. It’s kindness.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I mean, of course.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: There are people who go after your humanity, Sister, that tell you the light in your heart is a weakness. Don’t believe it. It’s an old tactic of cruel people to kill kindness in the name of virtue. There’s nothing wrong with love.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Love?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Have you forgotten the message of our Savior? It’s love of people.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I just feel as if everything is upside down.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: There are just times in life when we feel lost. It happens.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: And it’s a bond. Flowers.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: To remind me of Spring. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I should be going.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry your brother’s ill.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Thank you, Father. She heads for the path, stops.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You don’t?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sister. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Flynn is in the hallway reading a folded copy of T Daily News. Sports scores. He spots Father Sherman in a vestibule and they share a laugh. Noreen Horan approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: NOREEN
dialogues.text: Father, I think I’ve just got to tell somebody.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Hello, Noreen.

dialogues.speaker: NOREEN
dialogues.text: I’m in love.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful. Who’s the lucky boy?

dialogues.speaker: NOREEN
dialogues.text: Jimmy Hurley. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Have you told him? She shakes her head. Flynn sees Jimmy and looks in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Maybe you should.

dialogues.speaker: NOREEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I will, Father. She turns off Flynn’s look and goes after Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: NOREEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jimmy! Jimmy Hurley! Flynn follows her progress towards Jimmy and sees Donald. Flynn decides to dodge the boy, calls out to Father Sherm and ducks into the vestibule.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Father Sherman... Donald stands there a moment confused and disappointed. DONALD MILLER PASSES WILLIAM LONDON IN THE HALLWAY. William purposefully dumps Donald’s schoolbag and its contents. Donald stops.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You dropped something. Kids are stepping on Donald’s stuff as he gathers his thi He looks up. Father Flynn is offering his hand. Helps him up. Embraces the boy.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Sister James looks on. INT. SISTER JAMES’ CLASS - DAY Sister James is in a very bad mood. Some of the Kids are laughing. She snaps. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Be quiet. I said be quiet! The class gets quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: The next one of you that speaks out of turn gets sent right to the Principal! Now the question was: What was Patrick Henry’s famous remark? Jimmy raises his hand. She ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Donald. Now we go to Donald, who wasn’t listening.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Sister?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: What was the question? Nobody help him. Jimmy, put your hand down. Jimmy puts his hand down.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Donald Miller, stand up. Donald stands.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: What was the question, Donald?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: That means you weren’t listening.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: The question was: What was Patrick Henry’s famous remark? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Jimmy can’t stand it anymore and blurts out.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Give me liberty or give me death!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: James Hurley, down to the Principal’s office now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's wielding a long pole which is for changing light bu She has removed the old bulb and is screwing in a new one Her intercom rings. She doesn’t hear it. It rings again. reaction. Then knocking at her door, but she’s unaware. M knocking. The bulb lights and she senses something. She g to the door still carrying the pole. She opens the door t reveal MRS. MILLER, who is in her Sunday best, carrying a umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Miller?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Come in. Mrs. Miller starts in. INT. SISTER ALOYSIUS’ OFFICE AS SHE CLOSES THE DOOR - DAY And offers Mrs. Miller a seat.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Please have a seat. I was changing a bulb.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: I thought I mighta had the wrong day. You didn’t answer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shows 66.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (removes earplug) Huh? Oh. Well, just between us, I was listening to a transistor radio with an earpiece. the woman a for-the-era small transistor radio.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Look how tiny they’re makin’ ‘em. I confiscated it from one of the students, now I can’t stop listening to it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You like music?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No. News reports. Years ago I used to listen to all the news reports because my husband was in Italy in the war.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You were a married woman?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes. But then he was killed. Is your husband coming?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Couldn’t get off work. I only have a half an hour myself.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I see. Of course. It was a lot to ask.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: How’s Donald doing?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: He’s passing his subjects. He has average grades.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Hmm. Good. He was upset about getting taken off the altar boys. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Did he explain why?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: He said he was caught drinking altar wine.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That is the reason.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, that seems fair. But he’s a good boy, Sister. He fell down there, but he’s a good boy pretty much down the line.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: How is he at home?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: His father beat the hell out of him over that wine.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, he shouldn’t do that!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You don’t tell my husband what to do. You just stand back. My husband didn’t want Donald to come here.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: He thought he'd have trouble with the other boys. But that hasn’t really happened.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: That priest, Father Flynn, been watching out for him.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes. A knock comes at the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She goes to the door, opens it. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. He’s facing Sister Aloysius.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: James Hurley, what are you doing out of class?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sister James sent me down.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Talking.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, go back up and shut up! go! Go, Jimmy's shocked. Jimmy sees past Sister Aloysius to Mrs. Miller. Flynn appears behind Jimmy. Sister Aloysius sees and shuts the door. FLYNN’S POV - MRS. MILLER SITTING IN THE OFFICE - DAY As Sister Aloysius shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: (Irritated) None of your business! Go on! back to class.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Bullshit. Go (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What’d you say?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Jimmy, hurt, starts up the hallway. Flynn lingers, looks the office door, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SISTER ALOYSIUS AND MRS. MILLER IN THE OFFICE
dialogues.text: Sister Aloysius wants to get away from Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You have twenty minutes you say?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: It’s just that I have to walk to work.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Where is work?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Parkchester. If I don’t start cleaning by noon, I’m not home to let Donald in.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: May I walk with you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: I don’t mind. INT. SISTER JAMES’ CLASSROOM - DAY Sister James is doing a math problem on the board.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: ...eight sixty-fourths. Who can tell me what the common denominator is? Nobody? At this moment, Jimmy comes in the door and heads for his seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Back already, Mr. Hurley? (He doesn’t answer. She repeats harshly.) I said, back already, Mr. Hurley?!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (turns ) Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: Who do you think you’re talking to? This is my classroom, Boy. Don’t you forget that. The boy has sat down. Jimmy quietly breaks down.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Miller and Sister Aloysius walk along. It’s a green quiet place. A somber day. They come down a flight of ste

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Have you met Father Flynn?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Just seen him on the altar, haven’t met him face to face. No. Just, you know, heard from Donald.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: And what does he say?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, “Father Flynn, Father Flynn.” He looks up to him. The man gives him his time, which is what the boy needs. He needs that.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Miller, we may have a problem. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, I thought there musta been a reason you wanting to see me. Principal’s a big job. I just want to say though, it’s just till June.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Whatever the problem is, Donald just has to make it till June. Then he’s off into high school.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: If Donald can graduate from St. Nicholas, he’s got a better chance of getting into a good high school. And that would mean an opportunity at college.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t see anything at this time standing in the way of his graduating with his class.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s all I care about.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I am concerned about the relationship between Father Flynn and your son.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You don’t say. Concerned. What do you mean, concerned? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That it may not be right.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, there’s something wrong with everybody, isn’t that so? Got to be forgiving. (points) I work right there.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m concerned, to be frank, that Father Flynn may have made advances on your son.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: May have made.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I can’t be certain.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: No evidence?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Then maybe there’s nothing to it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I think there is something to it. I think Father Flynn gave Donald that altar wine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Why would he do that?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Has Donald been acting strange lately--?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: (overlaps) No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Nothing out of the ordinary? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: He’s been himself.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Look, Sister. I don’t want any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I don’t uhh...I’m not sure you completely understand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: I think I understand the kind of thing you’re talking about. But I don’t want to get into it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Look, I only have a few minutes. Not to be disagreeing, but if we’re talking about something floating around between this priest and my son, it ain’t my son’s fault.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m not suggesting that--.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: (overlaps) He’s just a boy.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Twelve years old. If somebody should be taking blame, it should be the man, not the boy.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know. I agree with you completely. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You're agreeing with me, but I got called to the principal if you know what I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I am concerned about Donald’s welfare.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You honestly think that priest gave Donald that wine to drink?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Then how come my son got kicked off the altar boys if it was the man that gave it to him?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know. The boy got caught, the man didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: So you're giving my son the blame.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: No problem my son getting blamed. And you know why that is?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should let me talk. I think you’re getting upset now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Sister, you ain’t going against no MAN in a ROBE and win. He’s got the position.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: And he’s got your son.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Let him have him then. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: It’s just till June.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Do you know what you’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Know more about it than you.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I believe this man is creating or may have already brought about an improper relationship with your son.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know I am right.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Why you gotta know something like that for sure when you don’t?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What kind of mother are you? A wind comes up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but you don’t know enough about life to say a thing like that, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know enough.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You know the rules maybe, but that don’t cover it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know what I won’t accept! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You accept what you gotta accept and you work with it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: This man is in my school.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, he’s gotta be somewhere and maybe he’s doing some good, too.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: He is after the boys!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, maybe some of them boys want to get caught! That’s why his father beat him. Not the wine.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What are you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: I’m talking about the boy’s nature now, not anything he’s done. You can’t hold a child responsible for what God gave him to be.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m only interested in actions, Mrs. Miller.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: But then there’s the boy’s nature.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Leave that out of it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Forget it then. You’re the one forcing people to say things. My boy came to your school ‘cause they were going to kill him in the public school. His father don’t like him. He come to your school, kids don’t like him. One man is good to him. This priest. Then does the man have his reasons? Yes. Everybody does. YOU have your reasons. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But do I ask the man why he’s good to my son? No. I don’t care why. My son needs some man to care about him and to see him through the way he wants to go. I thank God, this educated man with some kindness in him wants to do just that.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: This will not do.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: It’s just till June.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I'll throw your son out of this school.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: And why would you do that if it didn’t start with him?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Because I will stop this.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: You'd hurt my son to get your way?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: It won’t end with your son.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Throw the priest out then.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I am trying to do just that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Then what do you want from me? Sister Aloysius struggles for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Nothing. As it turns out.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: Please leave my son out of this. My husband will kill that child over a thing like this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I will try.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MILLER
dialogues.text: I’m late. Sister, I don’t know if you and me on the same side. I'1l be standing with my son and those who are good with my son. It'd be nice to see you there. Good morning. She goes, leaving Sister Aloysius, who is shaken. She wal away. A SUDDEN WIND ENGULFS HER. She struggles with the w and dead leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s raining heavily, and very windy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Aloysius hurries up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Aloysius walks down the hallway. She stops, experiences a moment of nausea, and then makes for her office. INT. THE PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY There’s a window open. Flynn appears. He has been awaitin her return.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: A third party would be required.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Yeah. What was Donald’s mother doing here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: We were having a chat.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: A third party would truly be required, Father. Why - - Flynn enters the office. INT. THE PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - DAY Flynn is in. He shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No, Sister. No third party. You and me are due for a talk. The storm picks up outside.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You have to stop this campaign against me!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You can stop it at any time.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Confess and resign.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You are attempting to destroy my reputation! A gust of wind comes in the window and blows some papers the floor. She goes to the window. She raises the blinds, shuts the window, flips the blinds open.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Who keeps opening my window?! What are you doing in this school?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’m trying to do good! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: (on her knees, picking up the fallen papers) Even more to the point, what are you doing in the priesthood?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You are single-handedly holding this school and this parish back!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Progressive education and a welcoming Church.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You can’t distract me, Father. This is not about my behavior, it’s about yours. (She stands upright)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No, this is about your unfounded suspicions.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That’s right. She starts arranging the papers.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I have suspicions.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Just leave that. It’s not important.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I will decide what’s important.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: WHY do you suspect me? What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You gave that boy wine, and you let him take the blame. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s completely untrue! Did you talk to Mr. McGuinn?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: All McGuinn knows is that the boy drank wine. He doesn’t know how he came to drink it.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Did his mother have something to add to that?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: So that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I am not satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Ask the boy then!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, he’d protect you.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why would he do that?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Because you have seduced him.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You're insane! You’ve got it in your head that I’ve corrupted this child after giving him wine, and nothing I say will change that.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: But this has nothing to do with the wine. Not really. You had a fundamental mistrust of me before this incident! It was you that warned Sister James to be on the lookout, wasn’t it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: That’s true.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: So you admit it!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I know people.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s not good enough!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: It won't have to be.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You will tell me what you have done!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Oh I will? The light bulb overhead blows out again.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Out again!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Sister James is convinced I’m innocent.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Oh, so you talked to Sister James? Well, of course you talked to Sister James.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Did you know that Donald’s father beats him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: And might that not account for the odd behavior Sister James noticed in the boy?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: It might.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Then what is it? What? What did you hear, what did you see that convinced you so thoroughly?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: It matters! What does it matter? I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Out this window I saw you grab William London’s wrist...and I saw him pull away.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s all?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yeah. That was all.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: That’s nothing! 83. He sits at her desk and writes in his book. Rain drums do outside.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: What are you doing now? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I'm writing down what you say. It might be important when I have to explain why you have to be removed.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: This morning, before I spoke with Mrs. Miller, I took the precaution of calling your last parish.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: The Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I did not speak to the Pastor. I spoke to a nun.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You should have spoken to the Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I spoke to a nun.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You know that’s not the proper route for you to have taken, Sister! The Church is very clear. You’re supposed to go through the Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Why? You have an understanding, you and he?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No, you have no right to go rummaging through my past!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You have a history. This is your third parish in five years. Why? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Call the Pastor. Ask him why I left! It’s perfectly innocent.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I’m not calling the Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’m a good priest!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You will go after another child and another child, until you are stopped.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: What nun did you speak to?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I won't say.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’ve not touched a child.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You have.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You haven’t the slightest proof of anything.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: But I have my certainty, and armed with that, I will go to your last parish, and the one before that if necessary. I’1l find a parent. Trust me, Father Flynn, I will.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You have no right to act on your own! You have taken vows, obedience being one! You answer to us! You have no right to step outside the church!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I will step outside the church if that’s what needs to be done, till the door should shut behind me! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do what needs to be done, though I’m damned to Hell! During last, she brandished rosary and then slammed it do

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You should understand that, or you will mistake me. Now, did you give Donald Miller wine to drink?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Have you never done anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: A mortal sin?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: I confessed it, Father!

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Then whatever I have done, I have left in the healing hands of my confessor. As have you! We are the same!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: No, we are not, we are not the same! A dog that bites is a dog that bites!

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Did you give Donald Miller wine to drink?

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Mental reservation? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You lie. Very well then. If you will not leave my office, I will. And once I go, I will not stop. She goes to the door. Suddenly, a new tone comes into his voice.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Wait! The RAIN STOPS. A silence falls.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I can’t say everything, you understand? There’s things I can’t say. Even if you can’t imagine the explanation, Sister, remember there are things beyond your knowledge. Even if you feel certainty, it is an emotion, not a fact.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: You will request a transfer, and take a leave of absence until it’s granted.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: You'd leave me nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: It’s Donald Miller who has nothing, and you took full advantage of that.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’ve done nothing wrong. I care about that boy.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ALOYSIUS
dialogues.text: Why? ‘Cause you smile at him and you sympathize with him, and you talk to him as if you were the same? You are a cheat. And that warm feeling you experienced, when that boy looked at you with trust, was not the sensation of virtue. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
